intro: Agalinis flava var. macrantha, commonly known as the yellow false nettle, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in whorls along the stem. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and along streambanks. Due to its delicate appearance and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
